abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Social Action Program
            Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The project achieved
            many of its objectives, institutional development was
            partially achieved, sustainability is likely, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First, it
            is possible to bring about improvements in a dire situation
            but it takes time, patience, and persistence. Second, in an
            environment subject to extreme political abuse, a
            prerequisite for delivering an adequate quality of basic
            services is improving governance. Third, it is necessary,
            from the start, to discuss a program with all levels of
            government that are involved in carrying it out. Fourth,
            Governments need to strengthen their financial management in
            order to give priority to social services or any other
            sectors. Fifth, provincial governments need to generate more
            continuity of senior social sector staff at all levels to
            improve basic social services. Sixth, sector investment
            credits worked well to establish a policy dialogue,
            influence expenditure programs, and exercise leverage.
            Seventh, supervision of SAPP is very demanding and expensive
            but the payoff justifies the effort and expense. Finally,
            when following a sector approach, IDA must be willing to
            deal with unexpected and difficult government policy initiatives.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Action Program Project will
            provide a multi-sector investment and maintenance credit to
            strengthen implementation of Pakistan's Social Action
            Program (SAP). SAP is the name given to Pakistan's
            overall effort to improve basic social services over the
            five year period 1993/94-1997/98. The Social Action Program
            Project will reinforce existing social sector programs and
            projects, whether or not aid-financed, by focusing on a few
            core problems that impede implementation throughout the
            social sectors. It will help finance the first three years
            (1993/94-1995/96) of the Program. For planning and
            monitoring, the SAP is divided into constituent
            sub-programs. The main ones include twelve that cover three
            basic social services -- primary education, primary health
            care, and rural water supply and sanitation (RWSS) -- in
            each of Pakistan's four provinces, plus the national
            population program. Others cover selected federally managed
            health and education programs and basic services in areas
            directly administered by the Federal Government. It intends
            to provide US$10 million to help promote community
            involvement and innovation in basic service delivery.
